Summary: Memory leak in irohad
Creator: gdshaw
Description:
Nettitude has found a memory leak in the Iroha daemon which can be triggered remotely. During a test run during which the supplied example script “tx-example.py” was executed 5000 times, a total of 1920288 bytes in 20003 blocks was leaked. This corresponds to an average of 384 bytes lost per iteration.

Taken to extremes, this behaviour could be used to mount a denial of service attack (although the number of transactions required would be large).

An attempt was made to demonstrate this using the ulimit command to constrain the amount of memory available to the irohad daemon. This was nominally successful, resulting in a segmentation fault, although fragmentation of the heap will also have contributed to that outcome.

The cause in all of the cases observed appears to be failure to delete the object returned by the function shared_model::interface::Transaction::makeOldModel(). Currently this is returned using a built-in pointer. In some instances this is then converted to a shared_ptr by the caller, but not all callers do this (and in any event, this course of action is less safe than using make_shared).

The safest solution would be for makeOldModel to be altered to return a shared_ptr, with appropriate changes at points where it is called.
Comment:
29/Apr/18 12:53 AM;neewy;Per the state of development branch (28/04/2018, 3404b17969f5899698f5683831d636865cab1b55)

This issue is not relevant since makeOldModel remains only in txGenerator, which is not used in irohad. A single test that has it is a client_test. This memory leak does not hold now;;;

Summary: Multi-signatory transactions can potentially be authorised by single user
Creator: gdshaw
Description:
In the function StatefulValidatorImpl::validate, a comparison is made between the number of signatures attached to a transaction and the quorum for the account:

tx.signatures().size() >= account->quorum()

This makes the implicit assumption that the number of distinct signatures is necessarily equal to the number of distinct users who have signed the transaction.

The signatures are stored in a container with set-like semantics (a SignatureSetType), therefore merely repeating the exact same signature will not trigger this vulnerability. However, if a single user were able to create multiple distinct, valid signatures for the same plaintext using the same public key, it would be possible for a single user to authorise a transaction which ought to require the signatures of multiple users.

It is clearly possible to conceive of digital signature algorithms which would allow this to happen, and ones which would not. Since the algorithm has been abstracted by means of a provider API, this means at the very least that there is potential for it to happen. Furthermore, the signature algorithm which is currently implemented (ed25519) appears to allow for the possibility in this instance.

In the function ed25519_verify (part of the iroha-ed25519 repository), the signature is passed in as a const_signature_t*. This is merely a wrapper for a fixed length array (unsigned char[ed25519_signature_SIZE]), and does not contain an explicit length field. It follows that any excess data beyond the expected length would be ignored.

Each signature is stored in an object of type SignatureType. Since the higher levels of iroha are not coupled to a particular signing algorithm, they do not appear to constrain what can be passed to that signing algorithm.

(There may, incidentally, be secondary issue if the signature is too short, however this is unlikely to be exploitable.)

This finding has not been validated by Nettitude, in part because there appears to be an error in the SignaturesSubet function: instead of checking that all of the signers of the transaction are signatories to the account, it appears to be checking that all signatories to the account are signers of the transaction. Consequently, it appears that all signatories must sign, even if the quorum requires a lesser number. Further investigation can likely be performed more efficiently by those familiar with the code in question.

To address this issue, Nettitude recommends checking that the public keys of the supplied signatures are distinct: it is not sufficient that the signatures themselves be distinct.
Comment: 28/Mar/18 7:41 PM;gdshaw;Looks like there is probably a similar issue with the chain validator - details to follow if it checks out.;;;
Comment_2: 30/Mar/18 2:36 AM;gdshaw;Proof of concept using appended random data failed to work due to conversion to a sig_t, which does constrain the length, however an alternative approach has been identified which does not alter the length: replacing the deterministic nonce generator in ed25519 with a non-deterministic one. Preliminary tests using a reference implementation were promising, now investigating whether and how this can be replicated in the context of iroha.;;;
Comment_4: 29/Apr/18 12:57 AM;neewy;This fix does not relate to transactions (since there is no test). I will report on the state of test as soon as it is in the codebase;;;

Summary: Vote early, Vote often
Creator: dhuseby
Description:
I believe I have found a method by which a rogue Iroha peer would be able to sign a block any required number of times, using its own keypair, in a manner that would pass chain validation.

The attack method is not yet fully proven, however I’ve been able to demonstrate multiple signing of a proposal, and the code for validating blocks is sufficiently similar that I can find no reason why the same method would not be applicable. In any event. I’d still like to create a working proof of concept if that is possible, but I’m badly out of time so far as the Nettitude assessment of Iroha is concerned, and I don’t think I’ll be able to do that without assistance from those more familiar with the code.

I’m nervous about saying this, in case there turns out to be a flaw in the method, but I suspect the impact of this finding would be “critical” if it fully checks out.

I’ve not entered this into Jira yet, since the submission form I have access to appears to lack the field needed to mark it as a security issue.

In outline, the method is as follows.

The root cause is that when signatures are assembled into a set, they are considered distinct if either (a) the public keys are different or (b) the cryptographic signature blobs are different. Furthermore, in order to determine how many signatures have been applied, the method used is to simply count the number of signatures in the set. The unspoken assumption is that if the same keypair is used to sign the same data more than once, then the signature  blobs will be identical and will not therefore be counted separately once they have been added to the set.

This is all well and good for a standard implementation of ed25519, because (unlike most digital signature algorithms) it uses a ‘deterministic  nonce’ – specifically, instead of generating a block of random data, it instead uses a deterministic hash based on the input parameters. So, if you repeatedly sign the same data with the same keypair, using standard ed25519, you will get the same signature blob every time.

However, whilst the specification says that you are supposed to use this deterministic method, the data in question is just functioning as a nonce – and the algorithm will continue working quite happily if you choose something different, like a random number. So, what I did was modify a copy of the iroha-ed25519 library to do this, build and install it, and then build Iorha against that library. The result is that if you then have Iroha sign something twice, the two signature blobs are different.

Now, you might ask why I’m considering it an attack if the attacker needs to tamper with the crypto implementation. The reason is that he need only do this on the node that he wants to turn malicious. The other nodes in the network can carry on running with unmodified crypto, and they will be able to correctly verify signatures regardless of whether it was the tampered or untampered implementation used to generate them. (In other words, it is only the signing function which needs to be modified – not the verification function.)

To confirm this, Nettitude arranged for a new proposal to be signed three times by the same account, then submitted to the Iroha daemon. The proposal passed validation, with signatures.size() equal to 3 inside the function StatefulValidatorImpl::signaturesSubset. This goes most of the way to showing that the security of multi-signatory accounts can be violated (corresponding to issue IR-2, which has been put into Jira). However, it appears likely that the same can be done for blocks – with much more serious consequences.

The mitigation is to check, by one means or another, that the public keys in a given set of signatures are distinct – not merely that the combination of signatures and public keys are distinct.

I need to finish the writeup for the security assessment now, but if someone familiar with the code were able to take an initial view on the viability and severity of this attack method in the next couple of days then that would be most helpful. Also, if it were possible to talk me through the data flow for signing a block – with a view to adding some additional, illicit signatures – then I can have another go at a proof of concept.

(Finally, if this does check out, Nettitude would be most grateful if a CVE number could be allocated – I understand you have a process for arranging this.)
Comment_2: 28/Apr/18 11:16 PM;dhuseby;It appears that the fix was merged on April 25, 2018: https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/commit/1c639d722ea3712a2292401d10a047360bc5206a;;;
Comment_3: 29/Apr/18 12:54 AM;neewy;Yes, it was merged and now this issue does not hold;;;

Summary: IP addresses can be made permanently unusable using the add peer command
Creator: dhuseby
Description: IP addresses can be made permanently unusable using the add peer command.  The solution is to provide a method for IP addresses to be reused.
Comment:
28/Apr/18 11:22 PM;dhuseby;The documentation for the add peer command indicates that a given IP address can only be added once to a given Iroha network (since it is a validation constraint that the address has not already been added).

A public key is specified at the time when the IP address is added. No evidence is required that the owner of the IP address is in possession of the corresponding private key.
There is not, so far as Nettitude has been able to determine, any mechanism for removing or modifying a peer once it has been added. Therefore, an attacker with the ability to add peers would also have the ability to permanently exclude any number of IP addresses from the network, by associating them with public keys not known to the IP address owners.

Adding peers requires the CanAddPeer permission, which would presumably be issued sparingly. Nevertheless, even though this attack may be difficult to carry out, the irreversibility of the effect makes it a significant cause for concern.

Further issues arising from this limitation are that:
 * A peer with reason to fear that its keypair has been compromised is discouraged from switching to a new one, due to the need to switch to a new IP address too.
 * A keypair known to have been compromised cannot be locked out.;;;
Comment_2: 29/Apr/18 12:58 AM;neewy;This is considered to be a design peculiarity, not a bug;;;
Comment_3: 18/May/18 10:38 AM;dhuseby;[~neewy] so should this be closed as not a bug?;;;
Comment_4: 25/May/18 5:21 AM;dhuseby;[~neewy] if this isn't a real bug, I'm going to close this.;;;

Summary: Update documentation for deployment of Hyperledger Iroha peer network
Creator: neewy
Description:
Right now there are few docs that explain how Iroha network is deployed and how resources should be provisioned:

Kubernetes [https://iroha.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guides/k8s-deployment.html]

[Ansible (contents are missing) https://iroha.readthedocs.io/en/latest/maintenance/ansible.html|https://iroha.readthedocs.io/en/latest/maintenance/ansible.html] [https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/tree/master/deploy/ansible]

Overall deployment doc [https://iroha.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guides/deployment.html]

There is also a contribution from Warchant available here: [https://github.com/Warchant/testcontainers-iroha]

We should come up with a meaningful set of documentation related to deployment. Since we have several means of deployment already, my suggestion is to move on with following docs:
 * how to deploy Iroha network manually, without any scripts whatsoever
 * how to use Ansible scripts for Iroha network deployment
 * how to use test containers library for Iroha network testing and deployment
 * how to deploy Iroha network in Kubernetes cluster

Such docs should include troubleshooting information on how to stop running network for updates, how to resume stopped peer, how to synchronize with the running network, how to create config file for Iroha and change the settings, etc

This is essentially a review of our deployment scripts so it might involve some discussions as well as bug revealing, that have to be put in this JIRA

Summary: OnDemandOrderingService: lost proposal
Creator: neewy
Description:
During ITF tests with Fake Peers in the bft-os trunk the following behaviour was sometimes observed:
1. During round `[i,0]` peer A gets a command from client and `OnDemandOsClientGrpc` starts propagating proposals: `[i,2]` -> B, `[i+1,1]` -> C, `[i+2,0]` -> A.
2. Consensus for round `[i,0]` is reached, and A's `OnDemandOrderingServiceImpl` switches to the round `[i+1,0]`.
3. A's `OnDemandOrderingServiceImpl`gets the proposal for round `[i+2,0]` from himself, but that round is already closed for incoming proposals, and the incoming proposal is stored for round `[i+3,0]`.
4. When round `[i+2,0]` comes, A asks himself for the proposal, but does not provide one. And no other peer gets the client's transaction submitted in the beginning.
5. When round `[i+3,0]` comes, some other peer is the ordering service, and the proposal stored in A is completely lost.
6. The client is unaware of the status of his transaction. In ITF it a timeout is triggered.
Custom field (Design): (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

Summary: Protocol/Interface validators
Creator: neewy
Description:
Now, protocol/proto validators work as follows:

* create an object from protocol
* validate its protocol part
* validate its interface part

The problem is that in some cases it is impossible to create an object from protocol, which causes run-time errors. So, the order should be changed, and ProtoFactory must accept not only a proto validator, but also a protocol one to have a possibility to validate protocol before creating proto

Summary: Documentation mismatch regarding deployment via docker
Creator: Audap
Description:
Link:
 [https://iroha.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guides/deployment.html#running-iroha-daemon-in-docker-container]

*Problem*
 The following command is not working as expected:
{noformat}
docker run --name iroha \
# External port
-p 50051:50051 \
# Folder with configuration files
-v ~/Developer/iroha/example:/opt/iroha_data \
# Blockstore volume
-v blockstore:/tmp/block_store \
# Postgres settings
-e POSTGRES_HOST='some-postgres' \
-e POSTGRES_PORT='5432' \
-e POSTGRES_PASSWORD='mysecretpassword' \
-e POSTGRES_USER='postgres' \
# Node keypair name
-e KEY='node0' \
# Docker network name
--network=iroha-network \
hyperledger/iroha:latest
{noformat}
Environment variables like POSTGRES_HOST do nothing since the parameters are hardcoded in `config.docker`:
{noformat}
"pg_opt" : "host=some-postgres port=5432 user=postgres password=mysecretpassword",
{noformat}
I guess the same applies to postgres image.

*Expected result*
 User should be able to change the configuration using environment variables as the documentation assumes.

* A side note*
Simple copy-paste and run is not working, user should remove the comments beforehand.

 We should also update the command with 'max_prepared_transactions' parameter
Custom field (Design): (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

Summary: Cross-domain privilege elevation via CreateAccount command
Creator: neewy
Description:
CreateRole and AppendRole commands do not allow to operate with roles that contain any permissions not owned by transaction creator.

The same check should be performed during CreateAccount command execution.

Let's consider an example. There are two domains. Domain A has default role with all the permissions. Domain B has default role with only can_create_account permission. Thus, any user from domain B can create a user in domain A and get control of the system.

*Acceptance criteria*

It is not possible to create a user in another domain if default domain role contains at least one permission that transaction creator does not have.

The case is covered by a test suite.
Custom field (Design): (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

Summary: Wrong response on getAccountAssetTransactions query (a non-existing account or asset)
Creator: neewy
Environment:
Querying account asset transactions from non-existing account produce TransactionsResponse with zero transactions inside. The same happens when you are querying non-existing asset.That is buggy behavior. The desired behavior is to return ErrorQueryResponse with StatefulFailedErrorResponse inside.

A missing account is an error that should be discovered during query stateful validation. A missing asset is also an error that should be discovered during query stateful validation.

*Acceptance criteria*
C344 and C347 cases (Get account transactions from a non-existing account and Pass a non-existing asset id) inside get_account_asset_txs_test should be enabled and pass.

Summary: Rework YAC storage with last block commit outcome
Creator: muratovv
Description:
Currently, if peer A sends vote with round \{3, 0} to peer B which currently in round \{5,2} then peer B sends back commit for round \{3, 0}. But the correct behaviour is to send commit for round \{5,2}. This change is required because of some reasons: peer B might don't have a supermajority of votes in storage, synchronization of the peer A will be faster because 

The task is to rework consensus: YAC and YAC storage with the corresponding behaviour.

The buffer should be passed a dependency for vote_storage. Tests which checks for of buffer and new vote_storage are required.

Summary: Update boost to 1.69
Creator: luckychess
Description:
It's impossible to build irohad_test with clang 7.0 currently because of compilation error with message "<experimental/string_view> has been removed. Use <string_view> instead." It's a boost issue and it was fixed only in 1.69 ([https://github.com/boostorg/asio/commit/43874d5497414c67655d901e48c939ef01337edb).]

We need to update everything to the new version of boost - docker, mac agents and may be something else.

Summary: Irohad system test doesn't call object destructors
Creator: luckychess
Description: When system test shutdowns irohad instances destructors of objects in application.cpp are not called. The reason for that is probably because we shutdown irohad with SIGKILL. This should be investigated and fixed.
Custom field (Design): (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
Comment:
23/Jan/19 8:47 PM;igor-egorov;Boost does not provide a cross-platform way for sending signals to a child process.

POSIX systems allow using kill for signals. On Windows, you will have to use WinSDK, OpenProcess, CloseHandle, etc.

We don't think that implementing the test only for POSIX systems is a good idea because the behavior will be different on Windows. Moreover, this approach will require using of ugly macro like #ifndef _WIN32.

The original concern is caused by the fact we do not test graceful shutdown of Irohad.

If we plan to test that, seems we have to create a standalone test and do not overengineer irohad_test.

 ;;;

Summary: Error building fuzzing targets if protobuf is missing in a system

Summary: Rework inheritance hierarchy with Command as an example
Creator: P.Kotov
Description:
Command class inherits ModelPrimitive, which inherits Cloneable. But, there is a problem - Command must not be cloned and thus this hierarchy is incorrect.

This can be solved, for example, by making ModelPrimitive and Cloneable independent from each other and using multiple inheritance in classes, where both are needed, and only one component in other ones.

Description:
The guide at [https://iroha.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/] currently says to use the "develop" branch to complete walking through the setup steps. However, the develop branch is out of sync with some of the latest work and thus the guide can not be completed. Specifically, step 2.2.6 will error out with:

root@4da8528d99f6:/opt/iroha_data# irohad --config config.docker --genesis_block genesis.block --keypair_name node0
[2018-12-17 20:58:52.675139633][th:10][info] MAIN start
[2018-12-17 20:58:52.678625432][th:10][info] MAIN config initialized
[2018-12-17 20:58:52.679557187][th:10][info] IROHAD created
[2018-12-17 20:58:52.679816831][th:10][info] StorageImpl:initConnection Start storage creation
[2018-12-17 20:58:52.681382095][th:10][info] StorageImpl:initConnection block store created
[2018-12-17 20:58:53.016889528][th:10][info] IROHAD [Init] => storage
[2018-12-17 20:58:53.022431376][th:10][error] MAIN Failed to parse genesis block.
[2018-12-17 20:58:53.022840041][th:10][warning] StorageImpl Tried to free connections without active connection

 

Recommendation is to suggest using the "dev" branch which does allow completion of this step

Old but 2 issues still remain:
 # One cannot remove peers
 # block hashing way does not seem very effective

h1. Current design

Currently block has the following structure:
message Block { message Payload { repeated Transaction transactions = 1; uint32 tx_number = 2 uint64 height = 3; bytes merkle_root = 4; bytes prev_block_hash = 5; uint64 created_time = 6; } Payload payload = 1; repeated Signature signatures = 2; }
where {{Transaction}} is another complex proto object.
It is stored in a ledger as raw file. One file = one block.

Assume we have a query "give me a transaction with hash H", and assume we build an indexing system to make queries efficient. In this case we make an index {{tx_hash -> block number}} to know the block number for each transaction.

Then, to query a single transaction, these actions must be performed:
 # find block with this transaction by looking at KV db (now Redis), normally O(1), if stored in hashmap.
 # given block number, query full block (read file, O(1) of ledger size)
 # for O(number of tx in block) search for given transaction blob.

IMO it is not efficient scheme, since query for specific transactions will be very frequent.
h1. Enhancement proposal

Store whole {{block_store}} in postgres:

Note: for now, ignore field {{role}}.

[!https://camo.githubusercontent.com/cd91d5852e81be3136c03c33f7296fd51d5a4be2/68747470733a2f2f692e696d6775722e636f6d2f30667062754c702e706e67!|https://camo.githubusercontent.com/cd91d5852e81be3136c03c33f7296fd51d5a4be2/68747470733a2f2f692e696d6775722e636f6d2f30667062754c702e706e67]
 # block is hashed (and therefore signed) with naive stream serializer (no protobuf, no boost::serialize), eg
struct Block{ uint64_t transactions; std::string tx_merkle_root; std::string prev_hash; uint64_t timestamp; std::string peer_merkle_root; }; template < class CharT, class Traits = std::char_traits<CharT> > std::basic_istream<CharT, Traits>& operator<< (std::basic_istream<CharT, Traits>& stream, const Block& b){ // explicit order stream << b.transactions << b.tx_merkle_root << b.prev_hash << b.timestamp << b.peer_merkle_root; return stream; } // just example, can be used separate class Serializer or Hasher. Block b; std::istringstream ss; ss << b; ss.str(); // serialized block, ready to be hashed and signed. Magic?
 # block has many signatures, 1-N relation. therefore we need {{signature}} table with signature details. it is also possible to remove {{id}} field in {{signature}} table and make {{<block_id, pubkey>}} a primary key.

 # block itself does not store transactions, they are stored in a separate table *Transaction*. Current proposal does not include specific TX fields in DB, BUT it is strongly recommended NOT to store {{HASH => BLOB}}, but store {{<hash, txfields...>}}, because of efficient indexing and search.

 # to proove that transaction exists in specific block, merkle tree is used. merkle tree is stored as binary tree with max number of leafs = {{MAX TX PER BLOCK}} (2^14 is good start). It can be stored in postgres, or in any (possibly) more efficient on-disk data structure. It is important to store whole tree, because hash calculation is expensive by means of CPU time and query of intermediate nodes in tree is frequent operation.

It works like this:
 * transactions are pushed to leafs, from the left to the right.

 * merkle tree is calculated during block creation, after we determined which transactions should be in the block.

 * merkle tree is persisted on disk.

 * whenever anybody asks to proove that tx belongs to the block, we answer with a proof - *a path*from leaf (this tx) to the root, so that the one can calculate O(logN) hashes, obtain merkle root and compare it with {{tx_merkle_root}} from block, which is cryptographically signed.

[!https://camo.githubusercontent.!|https://camo.githubusercontent.]

 # we have a requirement to add and remove peers on-the-fly. One way to solve this is to keep a list of available peers in the block and sign it, to prevent fraud. Problem arises: how to do it efficiently in terms of space? Because peers list may not be changed frequently, many blocks will have the same array and this is expensive in terms of disk space.

To understand who should have signed the block at the moment of block creation -- another merkle tree is used ({{peer_merkle_tree}}). It is used to proove that specific peer existed in the ledger at the moment of block creation.

idea is the following:
 * we maintain KV {{peer_merkle_root -> [sorted array of peer pubkeys]}} for all peer additions or removals. In other words, we maintain history of all {{peer_merkle_root}}s.
 * when new peer is added, we push his pubkey to the {{peer_merkle_tree}}. accordingly, when removed - we remove its pubkey from merkle tree, resulting in creation of new record (change) ini {{peer_merkle_root}}s.

Example: one asks who signed the block {{$given}}.
 # look at block {{$given}}, find {{peer_merkle_root}}
 # query array (lets call it ARR) of peer pubkeys from KV using {{peer_merkle_root}} from step above
 # PUBS={{SELECT pubkey FROM signature where block_id = $given;}}.
if:
 ** {{((len(ARR)-1) * 2. / 3.) <= len(PUBS)}} - number of signatures is more than 2/3 * N
 ** {{all([pubkey in ARR for pubkey in PUBS])}}- all pubkeys are in array of peers from ARR
then:
 ** answer with PUBS

Example: one asks, if peer A signed block 5?
 # look at block, find {{peer_merkle_root}}
 # find {{peer A}} in array of pubkeys by key {{peer_merkle_root}}
 # if found => it is a proof that he could not have signed tx, but definitely existed in the ledger at the moment of block 5 creation.
 # {{SELECT * FROM signature where block_id = 5;}}

This prevents storing redundant info many times, since we store only hash of pubkeys existed in ledger.
Custom field (Design): (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

Summary: Query replay attack
Creator: SaraG
Description:
Issue is moved from GitHub: https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/issues/1212

 

[#1062|https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/issues/1062] was referring to transaction replay, and because each transaction is stored in the blockchain, replays are prevented by looking up the blockchain index for the same transaction.

Since queries do not modify the state, each query is not stored in the blockchain, so the previous solution is not applicable for queries.
h3. Proposed solutions:
h4. Timestamp validation:
 # use the timestamp to keep it unique
 # store the timestamp from the last query from an account and require that any new query have a newer timestamp than that
 # reject queries with a timestamp older than 10 minutes with respect to local server time
 # delete the last timestamp used in a query by an account after 10 minutes

h4. Nonce validation:

This assumes that attacker can capture both request and reply, so that peer reply for the query is captured. User sends his first query to a node without nonce, and receives a signed reply with nonce from the peer. The nonce should be used for further interaction with the peer, so the next query from the used will contain the nonce it has received in previous reply from the peer. Nonce is updated on each query from the user. Each peer will maintain it's nonce for the user.
h4. Gossip protocol:

MST gossip module can be reused, so that peers will share data last query data for each user without consensus. Timing attack has to be performed if attacker wants to replay the same query on different nodes.
In case malicious peer will want to share his state with invalid timestamps, latest query hash can be used the same way as in transaction replay handling, but peers can also validate this hash if they want, because we store public keys of users, and users sign query hash.

Summary: Setup install step for C++ shared model
Creator: SaraG
Description:
Imported from GitHub: [https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/issues/1465]

I want to use C++ Shared Model on client side. Proper way to do this from client prospective of view is to write:

 

{{cmake .. -DONLY_SHARED_MODEL=TRUE   # or -DONLY_CPP_CLIENT=ON
make install  }}

Look [how I did this for iroha-ed25519|https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha-ed25519/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt#L145-L182].
Proper way to exclude unrelated to shared_model targets from {{make install}} step is to exclude them from {{all}} target, it can be done with property [{{EXCLUDE_FROM_ALL}}|https://cmake.org/cmake/help/latest/prop_tgt/EXCLUDE_FROM_ALL.html] ([example|https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha-ed25519/blob/08c58c9356a002e1f7c1a8f7f62f4084fc2861f3/cmake/ed25519_add_library.cmake#L57])

{{make install}} builds and installs iroha client library in the system:

 

{{/usr/local
├── include  # all include headers
├── lib      # libshared_model.\{so,dylib}
├── share    # cmake config file with version, so find_package(iroha_shared_model) will find it}}

currently I need to do all of these manually (copy include headers, there is no single {{shared_model}}target, create cmake, which is hard to reproduce from version to version.

I request to add this feature in current release, as soon as possible.

Summary: Command processing simplification proposal
Creator: SaraG
Description:
Moved from GitHub issue: [https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/issues/1528]
h1. Problem

Currently to implement own command type I need to:
 * write its interface in sm
 * write protobuf implementation
 * write executor
 * add command to commands.proto
 * (maybe something else I forgot?)

The point is that it is hard to do and I need to do changes in many places. No good.
h1. Proposal

Main point: use [interpreter|https://www.oodesign.com/interpreter-pattern.html] pattern.
 * transaction.proto becomes:
message Transaction { message Payload { bytes commands = 1; string creator_account_id = 2; uint64 created_time = 3; uint32 quorum = 4; } Payload payload = 1; repeated Signature signatures = 2; }
 * client side - *compiler* (C++ example):
#define OP_CREATEDOMAIN 0xfd class TransactionBuilder { // a-la stack std::vector<uint8_t> commands; ... TransactionBuilder createDomain( std::string domain_id, std::string default_role ){ // push command type commands.push_back(OP_CREATEDOMAIN); // push args. as example, push <length>:<contents> push_string(&commands, domain_id); push_string(&commands, default_role); return this; } }
data structures of arbitrary complexity can be encoded in this way with [1code|https://github.com/soramitsu/sora-specs/blob/master/1code-spec.md] ([bencode|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bencode] extention).

 * iroha side - *interpreter*:
std::vector<uint8_t> commands = tx.getCommands(); while(!commands.empty()){ opcode op = readOpcode(commands); // switch-case or handler map can be used: switch(op){ ... case OP_CREATEDOMAIN: { // this command expects to receive 2 strings as args: std::string domain_id = readString(commands); std::string default_role = readString(commands); // execute... } } }

h1. Features
 * complex and unnecessary code can be removed (lots of builders, interfaces, proto)
 * new commands can be added quickly with modifications in exactly 2 places (compiler, interpreter)
 * no proto modifications required to add new command
 * transaction becomes a flat structure. No [complex protobuf code to build clients required|https://github.com/Warchant/iroha-pure-java/blob/master/src/main/java/jp/co/soramitsu/iroha/java/TransactionBuilder.java#L44-L54]
 * ethereum [does the same in EVM|https://github.com/ethereum/cpp-ethereum/blob/develop/libevm/LegacyVM.cpp#L198], bitcoin [does the same in script|https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/script/interpreter.cpp#L281]
 * this can be a starting point to *smart contracts*. opcodes for stack management, state management and math can be easily added.

Summary: Unnecessary Protobuf backend usage in irohad
Creator: SaraG
Description:
Moved from GitHub: https://github.com/hyperledger-archives/iroha/issues/1678

Shared model design introduces a separation between model objects and their implementation. This reduces coupling to specific backends, such as protobuf. Unfortunately, during migration to shared model, it was not possible to implement all the functionality needed by Irohad using only interfaces.

This Issue describes cmake targets of Irohad which should not rely on the protobuf backend, but still do. For each target, necessary changes are proposed, so that it may be decoupled from the protobuf.
 * ordering_service: uses protobuf because it includes ordering_service_transport. Since ordering service is going to be replaced in the future, it is not necessary to change it at the moment.

 * raw_block_loader: uses protobuf to deserialize JSON objects. [#1662|https://github.com/hyperledger-archives/iroha/pull/1662] introduces interface for serialization of blocks, and it can be used instead of raw protobuf.

 * yac: big target which includes transport and storage. Can be split into several targets

 * common_execution - permissions' toString() function uses protobuf. We need to introduce an interface for that

 * synchronizer - not needed. Need to remove extra includes, and the target.

 * block_loader - can be replace with schema

Summary: Iroha slowed down
Creator: SaraG
Description:
Moved from GitHub: [https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/issues/1878]

 
|We executed Create Asset using iroha-Cli and created about 2.88 million assets.
 Then, the memory usage sharply increased, the operation of iroha slowed down, making it impossible to continue operation.
 At this time, the memory usage seen by ps aux and free was about 90%.
 Restarting iroha daemon and Docker did not change the situation, memory was used when daemon was started up, and slow down was reproduced.
 If 2.88 million assets are created, is it reasonable that the system will slow down with approximately 8 GB of memory used?|

 
  
  
|The size of the block store is about 2 GB. Even if this is all put in memory, it does not reach 8 GB, so I'd like to know quickly why 8 GB of memory is used and how to avoid using memory.|

 
| 
 The problem is that state restoring is implemented not the most optimal way (it loads all the blocks during the start to the RAM). Of course, the memory will be freed after daemon started, but possible memory fragmentation may cause slow down.|

 
| 
 It seems that memory has not been released after the daemon has started.
  
 Since swap is 0, we can not deal with it because we can not find the reason why large memory usage leads to slowdown, so we are in trouble.
 Why is it slowing down? How can I avoid slowdown?
 If memory is actually freed and fragmentation is the cause of slowdown, will it be possible to avoid slowdown by defragmenting memory after Iroha daemon is started? Please let me know if you know the concrete method.

Summary: Processing queries depends on the number of assets present
Creator: SaraG
Description:
Moved from GitHub: *[https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/issues/1918]*

If the number of assets created is large, the execution time of the query is delayed and the CPU usage rate is rising as follows.
 Is this reasonable? Does Iroha's ability to process queries depend on the number of assets?

What I did:
 # As a result of issuing queries (get_acc_ast) with 10 multiplexes in an environment where few assets were created, processing was completed in 7 seconds. The CPU usage rate was about 50%.
 # As a result of executing the same processing as 1 in an environment where about 14,400 assets were created, the processing was completed in 43 seconds. The CPU utilization was about 90%.

Summary: CMake Design for Faster Build Times
Creator: SaraG
Description:
Moved from GitHub: [https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/issues/1985]
h1. CMake usage
h2. Introduction

CMake is the build system used in Hyperledger Iroha. It is a complex system, with no single way to achieve the desired result. Some ways are newer and more preferable, however a lot of options that CMake provides have different trade offs and it is not clear which one to use.

The aim of this document is to analyze what methods of organizing the project exist, and which one achieves our goals, which are: fast build and separation of components from each other.
h2. Build performance measurement

Any discussion of build time without measurement is meaningless. In this case we are interested in build time of the whole project. Simple measurement can be obtained with time utility like this:

{{gtime -f "%S\t%U" cmake --build build --target -- -j6 > /dev/null}}

This will output system and user time of the build.
Notice that gtime is OS X specific. For Linux use /usr/bin/time (not builtin time!)

Of course, ccache must be disabled for the measurement since we are interested in compilation from scratch.

How precise is this measurement? Running this script 10 times and then counting average build time on a Macbook yields standard deviation of the measurement around 1%. This means that this method is precise enough to be used. We should consider incorporating it into our CI.
h2. Project Structure

Projects are organized in subdirectories with source files separated into physical components. The question is how to organize CMake to build these components
h3. Single Library

This approach consists of adding all source files of the project, into a single library, and then linking that library to an executable or tests.

This has several advantages:
 * Less linking required
 * No dependencies between libraries, which means more parallelism

However there are severe disadvantages to this method:
 * CMake file gets big
 * Every executable must be linked with the whole library
 * Every time change occurs, whole library must be relinked
 * Configuration cannot be different for different modules

This approach is used by a lot of projects, one of the examples is RocksDB database.

[https://github.com/facebook/rocksdb/blob/da1c64b6e75048068bf8599f198b8fe0e54eedfc/CMakeLists.txt#L462] - RocksDB CMakelists.txt where sources are defined.
h3. Multiple Libraries

This approach constructs each module as a separate library, which are then linked together for the final executable.

Advantages:
 * Libraries can be defined in their own directories CMakeLists.
 * Tests only need to link with required libraries.
 * Each library can have its own configuration (defines, compile options)

Disadvantages:
 * More linking required
 * More space for build directory

[https://github.com/ethereum/aleth/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt] - Ethereum C++ Client
h3. Difference in build time

In both cases, you must compile all object files for the resulting executable. So there is no difference in compilation time. However single library requires only linking a single library and then linking it to each executable. The multiple libraries option requires a lot more linking.

The total build time depends on how slow is the linking of the libraries. Usually linking is a just a fraction of compilation time.
h3. What to use in Iroha

Currently iroha is built as a set of libraries which are then linked into irohad executable and various tests. The impact of this on a performance is not very clear, and we have to measure link and compile time to get the picture of where most of the build time is spent.

If we want to reduce link time, it could be more beneficial to create a single target for all source files, and then add all executables to it. This however may be problematic since now we cannot separately configure concrete parts of the system.
h2. Test Organization

How to organize tests is an important question, since usually test code is bigger than application code. The general question is how granular test executables must be. We might have a single binary with all the tests from the whole project, executable for one module or one executable for each test file.

When we have single binary for a test, we must build everything in order to run a single test. However this compilation must only be done once, and all subsequent recompiles are as cheap as the other options.

On the other hand, having many executables increases total size of the build files, and as in the case with multiple libraries, more linking needs to be done.

At the moment, almost each test file is compiled into a separate executable. This leads to about 100+ executables being generated, all of which statically link necessary components. This leads to a huge code duplication, and a large amount of linking required.

To mitigate that, we can reorganize tests to have a single executable per module. This would lead to faster build time, less space wasted. However this might make it harder to profile tests execution time, since they will be joined together and hard to separate.

To do that reorganization, some code changes must be done in addition to CMake rewrite. One of the issues that I have encountered trying to do that, is the fact that a lot of functions in header files used in tests are not declared inline, which leads to link errors because of duplicate symbols. This is easily solvable, but may slow down the refactoring.
h2. Possible Build Optimizations

Now that we've seen basic information about project structure, we need to examine CMake and C++ specific options which can improve build time of the project.
h3. Unity build

Unity build is a C++ "technique" to improve compile times. It involves combining all .cpp files into a single big file, which is then compiled only once.

This has a huge impact on the performance of the compilation for several reasons:
 * file IO is drastically reduced single every header is included only once.
 * Every template is instantiated only once.

However unity build has major drawbacks, which prevent it from being just a drop-in solution:
 * Every symbol must be unique, since they will all end up in the same file.
 * Memory usage during compilation may increase significantly, since the whole combined file is compiled at once.

Effect of compilation speed varies, depending on the project and has to be tested.

Unity build can break correct code, for example when the same symbol is declared in separate files. This means that if we want to implement this thing for iroha, some substantial refactoring might be required.

Cotire plugin for cmake can create unity build targets by itself, and we should try that and see the benefit.

[https://buffered.io/posts/the-magic-of-unity-builds/] - about unity builds

Also as an example of Unity build we can check out Ripple project:

[https://github.com/ripple/rippled/blob/96c949a99791fdd077b091f682139a050cd1034b/CMakeLists.txt#L1331]
h3. Precompiled Headers

Precompiled headers does not solve problem of the clean build (for example for CI), however for development, they can significantly speed up the build. The idea is to precompile headers that rarely change (such as third party or standard library), and then use these precompiled headers when compiling targets. This significantly improves compilation time. However it has some limitations, such as only one header for a source file can be precompiled.

Both unity build and precompiled headers techniques are supported in cmake by cotire plugin.

[https://github.com/sakra/cotire]

Precompiled headers require us to carefully separate rarely changed header files into a separate header, which then gets included everywhere. Cotire seems to be able to extract 3rd party headers into a precompiled header, which needs to be checked for iroha project.

[https://clang.llvm.org/docs/UsersManual.html#usersmanual-precompiled-headers] - CLang user manual precompiled headers
h3. Modules Isolation

Even though performance is an important factor, we must consider also correctness of build configuration. To ensure that, modules must be as isolated as possible, to prevent unwanted dependencies. One of the big issues in this regardis isolation of header files. Currently, I can include every header from irohad into every file. This means that dependencies are not transparent, since we do not state in CMake, that this module depends on other module, even though I can include header file from that module.

This happens because we define global include_directories() for the whole irohad directory. This issue can be mitigated, if each library defines its own include directories. The drawback of that, with current directory layout we would have to change include paths, for example "ametsuchi/storage.hpp" will become "storage.hpp" etc. Whether or not that is a good thing, is a subject of discussion.
h2. Conclusion

As a main thing, I would like to get total build time statistics into CI as soon as possible.

As it stands, the easiest thing we can do to improve build times, is to reduce number of test executables. All other changes need to be investigated, since they may require some substantial refactoring.

As for the project structure, combining all components into a single library seems to present more issues than benefits, considering that the link time is not substantial part of the build.
Custom field (Design): (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

Summary: Atomic batch can be partially committed
Creator: igor-egorov
Description:
Iroha at master allows an atomic batch to be partially committed.

Let's assume that batch have two transactions. Both are stateless valid. When the first tx is stateful valid and the second is not, then the ledger will create two blocks - the first will contain the hash of rejected tx and the second - committed valid transaction.

 

If any of atomic batch transactions did not pass stateful validation, the whole batch should not be committed.

 

Probably we need to introduce a new error code for the case when tx stateful validation is failed due to another failed transaction within a batch.

Summary: Get status stream observable is asynchronous
Creator: P.Kotov
Description:
In the chaining of events, which can be seen, for example, in CommandServiceTransportGrpc::StatusStream, several threads can enter the same chaining lambda, for example, the "subscribe" one. This is not a correct behaviour, as only one thread must be there at one time.

To avoid problems, which arise due to simulteneous Grpc::Write calls, a mutex was introduced. When the environment become synchronous, it must be removed.

Summary: Doubling problem: Under load network creates 2 blocks within short time instead of 1
Creator: warchantua
Description:
I create a single peer, then use thread pool of 4 threads to send transactions like this (this is groovy):
{code:java}
IntStream.range(0, 100)
        .parallel()
        .boxed()
        .map({ n -> getTx(n) })
        .map({ tx -> api.transaction(tx) })
        .forEach({ o -> o.blockingSubscribe() })
{code}
 

[https://pastebin.com/aftZbGMh]

This is the log of block subscriber. It prints thread info, block height and block creation time every time it receives block from stream. It should get 1 block every (fixed) period of time, it is roughly equal to 1 sec. After certain block I start receiving almost immediately 2 consecutive blocks for 1 time slot (within 1 sec).

 

Look at blocks 11, 12, 13.

Block 12 was created after 1100 ms after block 11, then block 13 was created after 100 ms after block 12. This looks suspicious.

 

I attached the whole blockchain, where you can see "doubling" problem.
Environment:
testcontainers: 1 peer of RC2 started with default genesis block

iroha-pure-java: to send transaction(s), subscribe for block(s)

Summary: Make a MockBlockStore possible in Storage
Creator: P.Kotov
Description:
It is impossible to mock a BlockStore, which is inside Storage, as its construction is done inside the class and is highly-encapsulated - only path to the block store is passed. Because of this, some of the tests in PostgresQueryExecutorTest need to actually create and commit blocks, only in order to get a needed value of last_id() method, which is bad.

For example, one can introduce an overload of StorageImpl::create(..) with an already created BlockStore and then use it in AmetsuchiFixture to pass a MockKeyValueStorage.

Summary: Find a range and environment conditions when Iroha peer starts to process client transactions slower than usual (#of clients, #of transactions, #of peers, for TransferAsset command)
Creator: neewy
Description:
When Iroha network is configured for 4 nodes on nodes that are distributed across the globe in different data centers:

Using a cycle of values for #of clients and/or #of transactions sent by a client try to find a range of values when Iroha is capable of handling the load. 

"Capability to handle the load" means that the time to retrieve an initial status of a transaction does not increase way more than values for #of clients or #transactions. 
 
It is important to understand the overall degradation rate by gathering the data in a set of charts.

Summary: Test RPC endpoint `FetchCommits (BlocksQuery)` from a various number of clients with a different request frequency
Creator: neewy
Description:
When Iroha network is configured for a single node 
OR 8 nodes 
OR 15 nodes

On nodes that are not geographically distributed,
OR distributed across the globe in different data centers

And there are N clients, generating valid transactions, where N is 10 in power of [1,5] if possible:

Using a cycle of values for #of clients and/or #of FetchCommits queries sent by a client try to find a range of values when Iroha is capable of handling the load. 

"Capability to handle the load" means that the time to retrieve a committed block does not increase way more than values for #of clients or #transactions. 

Report on resource consumption in the environment with Iroha peer — how intensive the network is utilized? How much disk space and CPU consumed during N block streaming processes where N is 10 in power of [1,10] if possible. 

It is important to understand the overall degradation rate by gathering the data in a set of charts.

Summary: Supermajority checker dependency
Creator: muratovv
Description:
Currently, SupermajorityChecker uses as an in-place dependency in proposal and block storages. 

https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/855113729/POW+N+087+Byzantine+fault+tolerant+consensus


The task is to

* introduce supermajority checker as explicit dependency,
* add checker for 7f+1 first phase which returns 3 outcomes: Commit, Reject, Undecided
* add checker for 7f + 1 second phase: which returns Commit and Reject outcomes

There is a suggestion to implement a class which would store the exact requirements for commit/reject, so that CFT/BFT setting is easy to implement.

Summary: Database: synchronize access
Creator: Mikhail_Boldyrev
Description:
We use SOCI to access database. This library [is not thread safe|http://soci.sourceforge.net/doc/3.2/multithreading.html]. Currently we provide ownership of its internal objects to several classes (StorageImpl, MutableStorageImpl, PostgresWsvQuery, PostgresQueryExecutor and others) that have no synchronization in using them. Also we have an issue with closing a connection (which is a set of sessions) as we have no way to block until there are open sessions.

This task requests for a synchronization mechanism for all classes that use SOCI library derectly. Every time we pass a session object we should also pass an associated (single) shared mutex that the session users should have locked nonexclusively  while they keep the session and elevate to exclusive while they use it.
Custom field (Design): (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

11/Feb/19 6:00 PM;Mikhail_Boldyrev;done the deadlock thing, but the synchronization issue seems irrelevant.

We have to rework current broadcast with next loop propagation when the vote is not received by any of peers in the network. This is required due to supporting the asynchronous network and guarantee that restarted peers will see messages.

Summary: Deploy a soak stand with 8 peers and observe resource consumption and performance behaviour
Creator: neewy
Description:
Before our release, we need to prove that Iroha can process transactions without any worsened behavior. We would also need to document memory (RAM and disk space) and CPU consumption over time. 

I assume that we can reuse locust load tests in order to emulate the behavior of clients, which send transactions and queries in an arbitrary way. We might alternate existing tests with a list of most frequently used commands:

#0
CreateAccount, SetAccountDetails, GetAccountDetails

#1 
Commands:
- Add asset quantity
- Add signatory
- Append role
- Create account
- Create asset
- Create domain
- Create role
- Grant permission
- Set account detail
- Set account quorum
- Transfer asset

Queries:
- Get Account
- Get Transactions
- Get Pending Transactions
- Get Account Assets
- Get Account Detail
- Get Asset Info 


The task is to:
* alternate existing load tests in order to emulate a client that would most likely use Iroha
* deploy a test stand of 8 Iroha peers with resource and log monitoring
* visualise and store data in Graphana tool
* produce a report for this test stand per 1 day, 1 week and 2 weeks of operation
Custom field (Design): (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

Comment:
28/Feb/19 12:03 AM;saifullin;I added plugin GitHub Commit Skip SCM Behaviour Plugin":
{quote}Branches and Pull requests whose last commit's message contains (case insensitive) the pattern "[ci skip]" or "[skip ci]" will be ignored in Jenkins.
{quote}

In order to skip ci author should add [skip ci]  in commit message

This is the native way how CI can be skipped 

In multi-branch pipeline(which one we use)  no native options  to not trigger ci  if only some files are changed, it is available for another kind  pipeline job.
If adding  "[skip ci]" in commit message is not convenient  for users,  there are another solution: we can trigger to any commit,  but exit earlier if only  docs was modified.

[~neewy],  That do you think is "[skip ci]"  in commit message enough? ;;;

Summary: Slow clients may not receive the latest blocks if gRPC streaming (FetchCommits) is used
Creator: neewy
Description:
At the moment, if the clients receive the latest blocks over FetchCommits RPC call they might skip a block or more in between some processed block and the next, given by the endpoint.
There is an expectation that this endpoint should return committed blocks sequentially, as it it were a chain of blocks.

- FetchCommits `writer` should check for the result of method call
- FetchCommits should call `writer` from gRPC thread instead of main pipeline thread
Custom field (Design): (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

It is still needed to add runloop into FetchCommits and serve the result with writer->write via take_until;;;

Summary: Occasional rejects on transactions that were not put in the block store as rejected

Summary: Fix yac cold case tests
Creator: Mikhail_Boldyrev
Description:
This task requests either to enable or to remove YacTest.DISABLED_YacWhenColdStartAndAchieveSupermajorityOfVotes and YacTest.DISABLED_PropagateCommitBeforeNotifyingSubscribersApplyVote tests.

The tests passed successfully due to votes being equal and hence YacProposalStorage::checkPeerUniqueness(const VoteMessage &) returning `false'. This does not meet the `when' clause in these tests' description.

After the votes got appropriate signatures in https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/2134, the votes became unique, as they ought to be, and the mentioned tests failed.

Summary: Change the strategy for consensus vote sending: make peers send their vote over a circular buffer of peers
Creator: neewy
Description:
At this moment each peer sends every other peer its vote based on the order calculated from a hash of candidate block. This happens linearly — votes are sent in an order until the last peer is sent a message. Then peers are waiting for consensus outcome — which prevents them from reaching consensus in cases when more than f peers went down for some period of time.

The task is to rather use a circular buffer than a list of the peers and make them send the votes until the decision on the block was made (agreement was reached or not)
Custom field (Design): (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

The thing currently occupying the name 'round counter' is actually the ledger height, and we should call it so. The opportunity of switching to such scheme seamlessly is currently being researched.;;;

Summary: Review regex for domain names
Creator: frgomes
Description:
Related: [https://github.com/frgomes/iroha-scala/issues/5]

At the moment, a domain name must satisfy the following regex defined at
 iroha/shared_model/validators/field_validator.cpp:

  29 const std::string FieldValidator::domain_pattern_ =
  30 R"#(([a-zA-Z]([a-zA-Z0-9\-]\{0,61}[a-zA-Z0-9])?\.)*[a-zA-Z]([a-zA-Z0-9\-]\{0,61}[a-zA-Z0-9])?)#";

However (and apparently!) a domain name such as "example.com" is rejected by the server. Anyway, putting aside this observation, I would like to suggest that the regex gets revised in order to satisfy RFC1035 and RFC1183.
 * [https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc1035.txt]
 * [https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc1183.txt]

In this case, the regex should be, tentatively:
 (xn-\-)?((?!\-)[A-Za-z0-9-]\{1,63}(?<!\-)\.)+[A-Za-z]\{2,6}

*Examples of valid domain names*
 example.com
 example.co.uk
 morgan-stanley.com
 some.subdomain.example.com
 xn--arabic.example.com
 xn--katakana.example.com

*Examples of invalid input*
 test
 localhost
 morgan_stanley
 japan05

*Caveats*
 This regex would reject common domain names in use at the moment in test cases, like "test". Also, single word domain names currently being used in production at the moment would also break.

*Bibliography*
 Regular Expressions Cookbook, 2nd Edition
 Steven Levithan, Jan Goyvaerts
 8.15 Validating Domain Names

Summary: Block storage research
Creator: luckychess
Description:
Current block storage implementation based on flat files doesn't scale well enough for large (millions of files and more) volumes. We need to select a better alternative.

In general we consider 2 types of storages - relational and key-value. For relational Postgres seems an obvious alternative and for key-value different options are possible.

The task of research is to look at different storages and compare them using the next list of possibilities:
 * can we store blobs in it (specialised solution could be reviewed)
 * range queries support
 * random access support
 * runtime caches support
 * sharding
 * replication
 * easy to use dumps creation (blocks should be easy to view and transfer from one system to another for debug)
 * с++ api
 * lack of performance regression when database becomes big enough (at least numbers of terabytes)

Report should be provided as a table of compared databases.
Custom field (Design): (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

Summary: Find a way to overcome class member observer lifetime issue.
Creator: Mikhail_Boldyrev
Description:
Imagine an object that has subscribed some observable that uses its members to some observable. When such an object is destroyed, we need to prevent class members used in the observer from being destructed before the observer actually finishes and gets unsubscribed.  There can be different approaches to achieve this:

- When unsubscribing a subscription on an observable of an {{rxcpp::subjects::synchronize<T, rxcpp::observe_on_one_worker>}}, we would like to get blocked till there is an action in process for this subscription, but we don't. So we need to find a way to get blocked till the task is finished in order to guarantee the observer being unsubscribed will not run after we proceed.
In the example attached, we want the {{unsubscribe()}} call to get blocked till the running observer finishes. 

- We can isolate the so-called "shared state" into a dedicated structure and guarantee its lifetime by keeping it in shared pointers.

The task is to research the approaches (other ones can be suggested) to this problem.
Custom field (Design): (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

Summary: Investigate MST batches issue
Creator: igor-egorov
Description:
Short description: it was reported that under some conditions a semi-signed atomic transactions batch could be partially passed to stateful validation (what is an illegal transition).

Repro steps:

Create two users - each with quorum two.
Create an atomic batch that contains two transactions - one from the first user, the second - from the other user.
Sign the first transaction with the first valid signature and send the batch to Iroha.
Sign the first transaction with the second valid signature and send the batch to Iroha.

Expected result:
The batch should remain pending since the second transaction is not yet signed.

Reported behavior:
The first transaction goes to the stateful validation and fails due to mismatch of transactions quantity specified in its batch meta (two transactions).

Need to reproduce the issue.
Custom field (Design): (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

  In the case of the above program, it was assumed that 10, 10 and 1 on from the first transaction are output in order, but actually there was a missing or duplicate, and it was output as 10, 10 and 8.
  In case it is specified 21 for page_size to get all in the correct order.

        query = iroha.query ('GetAccountTransactions', account_id = account_id,

Description:
Currently, Iroha checks the size of messages only based on interface properties (e.g number of transactions, number of commands, etc). But in many cases, this type of checking doesn't fit well. For example, MST can share the whole own state but it could be pretty large.

The task is to create a limitation of message size in gRPC for prevention such kind of situations.
Note: take into account that different components may be changed by this task. There are required to check MST, OS/OG, YAC and block loader.

Summary: OS proposal creation strategy for good case optimization
Creator: muratovv
Description:
After merging https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/17 OS will contain a strategy for creating proposals. That PR contains a strategy which works well in bad case: if peer guarantees that reject will happen - it shares an empty proposal for all of them.

But the strategy can be changed with the following:
if OS receives f request, on f+1 request it will force the creation of a new proposal and will share it to f+1 and next peers.

The task is to create the described strategy and use it in the OS.

The minimum size of a scalar protobuf type is 32, while Iroha uses 16 bits for Quorum and TransactionsNumber. That means that several transactions or queries with different hashes may result in several objects with the same internal representation (due to type downcasts).

 

Need to refactor types. Probably upgrade them to uint32. Also need to check that nothing is going to be broken.

Summary: Clash of parallel status streams for one transaction
Creator: muratovv
Description:
Assume there is a transaction `tx` with quorum 2. Keys hold separately. Holders send signatures for `tx` parallelly to one peer. 

Status streams of holders may clash: the first holder may see statuses of the second and vice versa.
The task is to prevent streaming clashing for the status stream.

Summary: Back propagation of statuses for expired transactions
Creator: muratovv
Description:
In the corner case, when the transaction receives enough signature but the expiration time is over, the transaction will propagate to OS. But OS will reject transaction (but assumption).
The peer will not notify the client about the expiration of the transaction.

The task is to fix the behavior with back propagation of expiration status in the situation described above.

Summary: Trying to add New Node to Existing Network
Creator: thecodeotter
Description:
Here's the steps I take to create my problem.

1) Create a single Iroha node (docker container) and initialize the network
 2) Run a few transactions on this node so the blockchain gets some data. The transactions successfully commit.
 3) Create a second Iroha node (using the same genesis block with the 1st nodes docker ip) and join it to the existing network using AddPeer run on the Admin account of the first node. The addPeer successfully commits to a block.

4) The blockchain 'downloads' to the second node but then both nodes stall without explanation or obvious error message in the docker logs. They briefly talk to each other and then fail. The log simply stops producing messages. The consensus gets stuck.

Can you help me understand what my logs are telling me and get to the bottom of why the 2nd node isn't joining the network?

I have attached the script I use to launch both nodes. I have also attached the logs from the Iroha Daemons. The IPs in the files may not be right because I've been running this many times over and Docker changes the IP of the container each run.

I only suspect two places could be the problem. First

[2019-06-19 23:14:39.929374798][I][Irohad/Storage]: Cannot execute query. Fatal error. ERROR:  prepared transaction with identifier "prepared_block" does not exist  while executing "ROLLBACK PREPARED 'prepared_block';".

Beyond that I'm not sure

Summary: Add Support for Creating ‘IOU’ Assets
Creator: jsiegrist
Description:
This issue represents extending the asset model in Iroha to support creating IOU tokens. This extends the asset model in the following ways:
 * An IOU token represents two things - an asset and a link to the party who issued the IOU.
 * An IOU token must be able to interact with IOU tokens issued by other parties and with  asset tokens of the same denomination as the IOU tokens.

Once the enhancement template is transferred over to this Jira project, this issue will be updated with appropriate additional detail.

Summary: Fix Transactions' Collections Validation
Creator: igor-egorov
Description:
Now it is possible that a batch may contain two identical transactions (by its hashes, even not reduced hashes) or any other collection like a proposal or a block from a malicious peer may have two transactions with identical hashes. Every such a case has to be handled.

 
 1. TransactionBatchValidator(ListTorii)
 shared_model/validators/transaction_batch_validator.cpp
 Any batch that contains two or more duplicates of any of its transactions should fail its validation.

2. MST & OrderingGate & OrderingService
 irohad/multi_sig_transactions/transport/impl/mst_transport_grpc.cpp:85
 same as ListTorii

Ordering gate:
 irohad/ordering/impl/on_demand_ordering_gate.cpp:128
 removeReplays method has to be refactored (probably renamed) - it has to make proposal's transactions collection contain only distinct transactions. All the duplicate occurrences have to be removed from the collection.
 Such processing has to be done before collection parsing to batches.

OrderingService
 irohad/ordering/impl/on_demand_ordering_service_impl.cpp:57
 same as ListTorii


 3. BlockLoader
 irohad/network/impl/block_loader_impl.cpp:64

Maybe it is reasonable to add an additional validator class that will do the following:

3.1. A block received from the network should not contain two or more identical hashes in a list of rejected transactions hashes. If so, that block should not be taken to processing.

3.2. Any transaction hash from a list of rejected transactions hashes should not be equal to hash of any transaction from the main contents of a block. If so, the block should not be taken to processing.


 4. TransactionCollectionValidator
 shared_model/validators/transactions_collection/transactions_collection_validator.cpp:62
 Need to make TransactionCollectionValidator configurable via ValidatorsConfig struct.
 For block validation we need to add a rule: if a collection contains a duplication of any transaction, then a block has to fail its validation. This check should be performed before parsing the collection to transaction batches.

In case of proposal validation (ValidatorsConfig will reflect that), TransactionCollectionValidator should not fail validation if any tx duplicate appears.

Summary: Root permission
Creator: lebdron
Description:
It should be possible to use new permissions in existing network after a new permission is introduced. The task is to create a root permission which contains all existing permission, so that the user with this permission can create and append roles with new permissions to users. Root permission includes permission which can be granted by other users, so an account with root permissions can change quorum of any account, for example.

tl;dr: The root permission allows to execute all kinds of commands and queries (even when required for a command or query permission is not explicitly assigned to the owner of root permission).

Summary: Complete Query & Command base interfaces
Creator: Mikhail_Boldyrev
Description:
Currently creator account & query hash are passed to SpecificQueryExecutor separately from Query object. These must be instead moved to Query interface via getters. This is because the Query interface should represent an entity that is ready to be executed, while without these fields it is only part of that entity. This seems like a low-level optimization erroneously made its way to the top level interface, which should instead be agnostic to low-level stuff and represent logical entities instead.

Same thing with creator and Command.

Summary: Framework for checking business logic
Creator: ekovalev
Description:
Existing Integration Test Framework has functionality for checking business logic of commands but it employs the entire pipeline. Running test in the ITF requires lots of various status messages to be provided by the framework which is hard and error prone. Another downside is that it makes the whole testing runtime duration much longer.

The idea is to extract the business logic testing functionality in a form of a separate light-weight framework and rework the respective tests to run within this framework.

This document explains the rationale behind this idea and the proposed solution in more detail [https://docs.google.com/document/d/15wc4oO9CV0oOy9jrPn3Qze9XpzyMB5S1rnJce0QhqII] .

Summary: Redesign async layer
Creator: ekovalev
Description:
The motivation for this epic is outlined in the design document [https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/1201176581/POW+N+093+Transport+and+async+layers+redesign].

In current async layer design the RxCpp framework is used to deal with asynchrony. In large applications it can lead to a number of problems, including (but not limited to) bloated binary, opaque thread pool management, difficulties controlling objects lifetime etc.

The same functionality in Iroha case can be achieved by other means, which will allow to simplify the code, reduce binary size, improve code maintainability and readability, improve performance and make debugging easier (by controlling thread pools). Ultimately, it would mean faster product development.

Summary: Interfaces for the consensus module
Creator: ekovalev
Description:
This task is the initial step on the way to having a pluggable consensus in Iroha.

The idea is to create a set of interfaces whereby the consensus would interact with other system components, possibly borrowing ideas from existing blockchains but also staying withing reasonable constraints set by the existing Iroah implementation (that is we want to modularize the consensus part without major pipeline refactoring unless necessary).

Consensus/blockchain to look at include:
 # Parity Ethereum ([https://github.com/paritytech/parity-ethereum])
 # BFT Smart ([https://github.com/bft-smart/library])
 # Concord ([https://github.com/vmware/concord-bft])
 # Honey Badger ([https://github.com/poanetwork/hbbft])
 # Tendermint ([https://github.com/tendermint/tendermint)|https://github.com/tendermint/tendermint]
 # Sawtooth PBFT ([https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-pbft)]

The outcome of this activity could be a document similar to[ https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-rfcs/blob/master/text/0004-consensus-api.md|https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-rfcs/blob/master/text/0004-consensus-api.md])

Summary: change asset amount format in transport
Creator: Mikhail_Boldyrev
Description:
in v1 we have asset represented by decimal string with a dot. it implies several problems with parsing and uniqueness, which bring counter-intuitive rules and complex parsing algorithm. This can be easily avoided if we switch to binary amount representation.

 

This task demands changing the format of asset amount to binary format as described in the doc ("using integers" section). This affects client API and internal block format.

 

Technical description: https://wiki.hyperledger.org/display/iroha/Asset+Amount

Summary: rework query error response reason and error_code
Creator: Mikhail_Boldyrev
Description:
currently query error response has two fields with overlapping content meaning: reason and error_code:

!0.png!!1.png!

As we can see, some stateful error conditions are present in reason, and some - in error code. some of them are in both (depending on query).

 

This approach may be misleading, because sometimes only reason provides the error type (no account in GetAccount), sometimes only error code (invalid pagination), and sometimes both. But it is part of v1.0 API and cannot be changed in backwards-compatible way.

 

The task demands to remove this ambiguity of error classification techniques. We can either remove stateful error subtypes from reason and leave them only in error code, or leave only one field of reason and code, that will provide exact error kind in global or query-specific scope respecitvely.
Attachment_2: 09/Nov/19 4:15 PM;Mikhail_Boldyrev;1.png;https://jira.hyperledger.org/secure/attachment/17923/1.png
Custom field (Design): (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

Creator: bot_soramitsu
Description:
on docker container after bash scripts/run-iroha-dev.sh

```
iroha-ci@66078cb9d601:/opt/iroha$ cmake -H. -Bbuild -DCMAKE_TOOLCHAIN_FILE=/opt/dependencies/scripts/buildsystems/vcpkg.cmake -G "Ninja"
-- ccache enabled (/usr/bin/ccache)
CMake Error: CMake was unable to find a build program corresponding to "Ninja".  CMAKE_MAKE_PROGRAM is not set.  You probably need to select a different build tool.
CMake Error: CMAKE_C_COMPILER not set, after EnableLanguage
CMake Error: CMAKE_CXX_COMPILER not set, after EnableLanguage

iroha-ci@66078cb9d601:/opt/iroha$
```

any ideas ?
Custom field (Design): (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
Comment:
13/Nov/19 3:58 AM;claudiocandio;I think this is because the docker image hyperledger/iroha:develop-build doesn’t have the ninja-build package installed

You would need to add the ninja-build in docker/develop/Dockerfile like this:
 - - build-essential clang-6.0 lldb-6.0 lld-6.0 g++-9 \
 + build-essential clang-6.0 lldb-6.0 lld-6.0 g++-9 ninja-build \

Then rebuild the docker image locally as described here docker/develop/README.md:
 $ docker build -t hyperledger/iroha:develop-build -f docker/develop/Dockerfile .

I tried this and it worked ok to me

Docker image hyperledger/iroha:develop-build in Docker Hub should be updated as well to include the ninja-build package for those who download it

Hope this helps;;;

Summary: add target account to GetPendingTransactions & controlling permission
Creator: Mikhail_Boldyrev
Description:
Anton Khvorov, [25.02.20 07:37]
lebdron ea_kovalev 
Добрый день джентельмены!
Подскажите по поводу возможности реализации квери на получение МСТ транзакций, связанных с аккаунтом? Сейчас похожий фукнционал реализован в D3/SoraNet, но выглядит он не очень удобно, потому что пользователь должен "логинится" в чей-то чужой аккаунт с своей ключевой парой и отправлять квери уже с аккаунт ид этого "чужого" аккаунта, подписывая его своей ключевой парой, которая является сигнатори в этом "чужом" аккаунте.

Хочется видеть сценарий где пользователь А с аккаунтом M добавляет к себе в сигнатори пользователя B с аккаунтом N и каждый раз, когда пользователь А будет генерить МСТ транзакцию на аккаунте M, пользователь B мог закверить пендинг транзакции со своего аккаунта N, не "логинясь" в аккаунт M (то есть не кверя транзакции на "чужом" аккаунте М)

Mikhail Boldyrev, [25.02.20 07:48]
[In reply to Anton Khvorov]
в модели ирохи это выглядит больше как grantable permission без костылей с сигнатори. надо добавить опциональное поле account в GetPendingTransactions (для совместимости если оно не установлено, считаем что там автор квери).

Bogdan Mingela, [25.02.20 09:24]
Да, грантабл пермишн действительно выглядит логичным, но нужно также уметь в рантайме "забирать" этот пермишн. Вдобавок, нужно либо модифицировать логику исполнения "GetPendingTransactions", либо пользователю придется где-то хранить список аккаунтов, которые загрантили ему такой пермишн.

Summary: Simple CLI for the Utimaco Block Safe HSM simulator
Creator: ekovalev
Description:
Develop a simple CLI application to interact with the Utimaco HSM simulator via a C-language SDK it provides. Such CLI should allow inserting keypairs into the wallet and signing some content.

On a broader note, the motivation for this task is to prove that the Utimaco HSM cryptography is compatible with what is being used by Iroha node. Such proof is equivalent to demonstrating that signing an arbitrary set of messages with the same private key inside the HSM module and by an Iroha client library will produce identical outcomes.
